publicationStmt.publisher: New York Public Library for the Performing Arts

titlePart.title: The Wizard of Oz: A MUSICAL COMEDY A Dramatic Composition in Three Acts

div.head:
-:- "THE WIZARD OF OZ" -:-
-:- ACT I,-:-
div.stage: At the rise of the curtain farm hands discovered. House servants are busy performing their various duties. One man on a wheat rack, Servants cleaning pans, etc in front of the house. Several girls enter carrying apples. They pelt the man on the wheat stack. Farm wagon with horse enters. Suddenly old man reading paper, rises and points to the approaching cyclone. Connection on part of everyone. They all excitedly and frantically rush off stage. The cyclone effect is worked upon the gauze. The scene then changes. When the lights go up Chorus discovered all dressed in blue and posed about a Maypole. A Maypole dance follows. Then the entrance of the Wicked Witch. She drives them about the stage until someone calls her attention to the approaching cyclone. All rush about wildly. Lights gradually go out. When they go up again, a house similar to the farmhouse of the Kansas Scene is discovered E.
It is in a delapidated condition.

div.head: -:- ACT I -:-
div.stage: SCENE I:- Descriptive Tableau, showing Kansas Prairie Farm, the cyclone, ascent of the house with Dorothy, and transformation to
SCENE II:- The munchkin country - Land of Oz followed by the descent of the house crushing of the wicked witch, etc.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Here's a catastrophe!

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: What a dreadful storm.

sp.speaker: 3rd Girl
sp.p: Never in the land of Oz has there been one like it.

sp.speaker: 4th Girl
sp.p: I wonder from what unknown country the storm blew this house.

sp.speaker: 5th
sp.p: Such a strange dwelling - so different from ours.

sp.speaker: 6th Girl
sp.p: The same storm that brought this shouse has blown half of our home away.

div.stage: (Noise off stage, shouts, cries, etc. Voice off stage. Reuben's)

sp.speaker: Reuben
sp.p: Bring her along.

sp.speaker: 8th Girl
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: 9th Girl
sp.p: Somebody under arrest. A strange looking girl.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: A witch, perhaps.

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: The storm may have been her work.

div.stage: (Enter Reuben and Simon with Cynthia. R. #3. Cynthia suggests madness in her costume and make-up.)

sp.speaker: Reuben
sp.p: Here's an enchantress. Do any of you know her?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Who are you, and where do you come from?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: My name is Cynthia, and I am a lady lunatic.

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: Does the asylum know you are out?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Fear nothing. I am not dangerous.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: I've lost my reason.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: She's a sorceress. To the river with her.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: That's no way to treat a perfect lady lunatic.

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: If you sink we'll believe you.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: But I will not sink. I've been taking swimming lessons from a banker.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Swimming lessons from a banker?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Yes he told taught me how to float a loan.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: To the river.

div.stage: (They advance to her. Witch of the North enters and halts them)

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Halt! What would you do with this girl?

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: She's a sorceress, and her spells produced the recent cyclone.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Then you should thank her on your knees. The storm has made you free.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Free?

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: It dropped that house upon your cruel tyrant, the Wicked Witch. Her cruel spells and wicked enchantments have caused you endless misery. She hated love and happiness, and while she lived would not permit you to know them.
If you are a member of the Sorceress' Union show your card.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: I haven't one. I have never sorcered. I am only a sweet girl maniac. Listen, and I will tell you my story.
I was once a saleslady in one of our largest department stores.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Ah, yes, I have seen your open face at an opening sale of umbrellas that wouldn't open.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: No, I was at the alligator counter in the animal department. I was engaged to a young musician named Niccolo Chopper who played the piccolo.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Poor girl!

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: He was so generous. As soon as our wedding day was fixed he gave me my alimony in advance.

sp.speaker: 6th Girl
sp.p: Where is he now?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: The Wicked Witch enchanted him. He never returned.

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: How do you hope to find him?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: By whistling his favorite tune. No matter what the witch may have made of him, if he hears the tune he will answer.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Did he play it often?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: For hours at a time. You can't imagine how he objected to a change of air.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: You doubtless learned to love it?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: True. And on moonlight nights he would always play it in the vegetable garden back of my semi-Queen Anne suburban boarding house.

div.head: NICCOLO'S PICCOLO

lg.l: Not with the twinkling lute
Sought he to press his suit
Nor with the sighing flute
Came he zum-zumming
Nor on, the gay guitar
Under the twilight star,
Could he be heard afar
Softly a strumming.
But, on the piercing piccolo, my highly-gifted Niccolo
Could charm with much celerity, a melody divine.
Defying fell malaria, He'd execute his aria
With marvelous dexterity, each night at half past nine.
Not with a slide trombone, were his soft pleadings blown
Lacking were they in tune, blatant and blaring
Nor with the violin, sought he, my heart to win
Playing that garden in, his love declaring.

div.stage: Cynthia and Chorus, all exeunt at end of whistling refrain. [HANDWRITTEN: Using Piccolos]
Enter Witch of the North and Girl, L.2.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Where did you say this house came from?

sp.speaker: 3d Girl
sp.p: From the skies, your highness.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: A strange abode from some unknown land.

div.stage: Sir Dashemoff Daily, enters hurriedly, L.3.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: News! Wonderful news!

sp.speaker: 3d Girl
sp.p: Of whom?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pastoria, the rightful king of Oz, has returned on the wings of the wind.

sp.speaker: 3d Girl
sp.p: Are you sure of that, Sir Dashemoff?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: The cyclone blew Pastoria home again. Aided by General Riskitt he has started a revolution already.

sp.speaker: 3d Girl
sp.p: Where's Pastoria going to find the money for his revolution?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: He's selling reserved seats for his own coronation.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: How came King Pastoria to leave the land of Oz?

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: One day, years ago, a balloon brought to the Emerald City a mysterious man from a mysterious place they call the earth.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: I've read about it in our children's books.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: The stranger lured Pastoria into the balloon and cut the ropes. It bore Pastoria through the clouds. The stranger remained and, because of his mystic arts, was crowned King of Oz.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: If Pastoria gets his throne away from the Wizard of Oz, it will be hard luck for me. I'll have to grind out a new royal anthem.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Pastoria approaches.

div.stage: (Crowd retire up stage. Enter TIMOTHY, followed by RISKITT, L.3.E.)

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Halt! His Majesty would address the army.

div.stage: (Pastoria enters in motorman's coat and hat. He carries in one hand a large sceptre and a shawl strap. In the other a gilded hat box with crown inside.)

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p:
My faithful soldiers. As I gaze upon your faces it gives me
great pleasure to know that you all may die for me.
Men with faces like yours ought to die for somebody. - and I'm as good an excuse as you'll ever get.
When you face the enemy, chanting your battle hymn, -- where's that battle hymn?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: All ready, sire.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: This ought to make heroes of you all.

lg.l: "When we were children we cried for Pastoria, -
When we were young we sighed for Pastoria, -
When we grew up we died for Pastoria. -
Oria, oria, peerless Pastoria."

sp.p: When we were children we cried for Pastoria! Now, wouldn't that wilt the feathers on Maud's new boa!
You shall restore me to my rights. As for the cheap swindler who has stolen my throne - The Wizard of Oz, --

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Where will you find a greater scoundrel, a more contemptible being, than that Wizard of Oz?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Hear! Hear!
No, - no! I mean, where?
As for your pay, have no fear. As we approach the capitol I will dispose of reserved seats for my coronation at speculator's rates.

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: S-sh --! A customer approaches.

div.stage: (Pastoria and Riskitt quickly produce box office diagrams and bunches of tickets from their pockets as SOPHRONIA and PETER enter R.1.E. they rush upon them in the manner of ticket speculators.)

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Tickets for Pastoria's coronation?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Two on the center aisle, four rows from the front.

sp.speaker: Simon
sp.p: He's a speculator.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Down with him.

div.stage: (Enter CYNTHIA, R.3. Come down through crowd, C.)

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Wait. He may be my long-lost Niccolo.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I'm nobody but the King. For years I ruled the Land of Oz and was the best dressed little king that ever tied a four in hand. The people loved me then, and called me their Tony Pastoria.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: I pray thee, play upon this piccolo.
The wicked witch may have changed my sweetheart into you; How perfectly awful!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I'm not your sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Then prove it by playing "The Carnival of Venice" with variations.
There was a bum note in the crescendo that Niccolo could never avoid.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: The idea! Open that box.
sp.stage: (Points to hat box. Riskitt opens it.)
sp.p: What's the name in the crown of that crown?

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Pastoria II.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: It was on my head when that confounded balloon carried me away. It fitted me then, and it fits me now.

div.stage: (Puts it on his head triumphantly. Movement of surprise in crowd.)

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: What's the meaning of that queer costume?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: When the cyclone picked me up I was working as a motorman in Kansas.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: What's a motorman?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Well, a motorman is a fellow that takes life easy. He's a regular lady killer, and a sort of business agent for the Undertakers' Union. When I reached the earth I had to do something for a living.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Your Majesty had to work? Terrible!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p:
Yes. Your Majesty had to eat. I grew so desperate I decided to stop at nothing, so I became a motorman. It's a merry
life, and all day long the jingling of the bells. A fellow- motorman tried to get me to go with him to Michigan and motor there.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: He said the girls were more sociable. He used to sing a beautiful song about one of them.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Was it soulful?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Well, you can judge for yourself.

lg.l: I'm fond of the girls from Tennessee,
For they are extremely coy,
But there's another girl for me, she's the girl from Illinois.
With the damsel fair from gay Delaware
I'd giddily coquette.
But the girl for me beyond compare, in old Michigan is met.
In Michigan, In Michigan, I would that I were rich again.
A ticket I'd buy, and away I'd fly
To the far-off fields of Michigan.
In Michigan, In Michigan, my tent I'd like to pitch again.
I've a sweetheart true in Kalamazoo
And that's what I've got in Michigan.
The Georgia girl is a perfect peach,
The Maine girl takes the bun
Of the Oregon girl I love to preach
For she second stands to none.
Oh the Texas girl is a downright pearl,
And a dainty dream besides,
But the girl that can give them all a twirl,
In old Michigan resides.
I've a sweetheart true in Kalamazoo,
I've a mother-in-law in Saginaw, etc.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: You are not like my Niccolo, and yet seem to be he. If I could see you make love to someone else -- my Niccolo would never do that in my presence.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Pasty! Pasty! Where are you, darling?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: You'll have a chance, for here comes my fiancee.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: A woman!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Yes. She was a waitress in the railroad station at Topeka. Her name is Tryxie.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Tryxie?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Yes. We were blown out of Kansas at the same time. When the cyclone struck town I was standing on the front platform of my car and had just yelled, "Hold fast for a sharp curve". As we sailed over the roofs a beautiful girl suddenly shot out of a neighboring cloud and hit my dashboard. She was carrying a plate of beans. She said she was going my way and before the cyclone dropped us through yonder chestnut trees we were engaged.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Darling, I hope you won't think me gross, but I wish you would take me by the hand and lead me to a large porterhouse steak.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Girl, the stake that I am fighting for is not a porterhouse. I may be slain. Then what would lovey do if dovey died?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Why lovey would die too.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Do you remember, I met you as a motorman.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: I was struck by you at our first meeting.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: You were carrying a book.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Roosevelt's Memoirs.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I ran over them without asking you.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Because you got the bell to go ahead.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Then I went ahead to get the belle.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: You couldn't have offered me a palace then.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: No. About all you could expect from a street car man is "a little room up front."

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: What were your prospects then?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Same as the conductors' - only fare.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: And yet you loved me then.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I yearned for you.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: And you love me now?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: With all the heart a motorman is allowed to have.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Pasty, you are just too awful!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: To resume -- how much does oo love oosey?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: OO's OOsey?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: OOS.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Enough. I am convinced. My Niccolo could never hand out such a tart line of wedding march conversation.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Is this a lady detective?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: No. This is a lady lunatic.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Yes; mad through with blighted love. Now will I to the vegetable garden where I last saw him.

lg.l: "Oh, he never more will come,
And I wonder where he's went.
Hey nonney, hey nonney hey!"

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Poor thing -how she loved him! Niccolo must have been very handsome.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Yes. I reminded her strongly of him.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: But, she is a lunatic. That explains a lot of things.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Tryxie, you see what it is to lose a fond lover. Now suppose, suppose you were to lose me?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Pastoria, you know I never was lucky.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I know. But, what would you do?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Why, someone else, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: But tell me, what do you think of the country you're to reign over as my queen?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Oh, well enough as far as I've gone. But it was a bad time to leave Kansas.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Barnum's circus was billed for our town for the 13th, and next to a Boston cream puff I love a circus.

div.head: -- "WHEN THE CIRCUS COMES TO TOWN" --

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Well, where am I at?
Surely, this isn't Kansas?
Imogen, we are lost, and we'll never see home again. How poor Father will miss us.

You were the only thing to prove he ran a dairy. Now he won't be able to mix up any more milk until I get back with the key to the plaster of Paris barrel. I wish we could run into another cyclone going the way we came from.
What are you crying for?
Be brave, like me. Will somebody tell me the way back to Kansas.
My! but our house is bent. Well, if the cyclone hasn't blown Carrie Barry's front door right on our porch. There's her name on the doorplate. Hello! what's this?
sp.stage: (Takes folded paper from door. Reads it.)
sp.p: "To the Princess within." Here's a joke, Imogen.
Why it's a love song from a perfect stranger.

div.stage: (Enter WITCH of the North, and SIR DASHEMOFF DAILY, L.2.)

sp.speaker: Dashemoff
sp.p: There she is, your Highness.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Whence comes this maiden?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I know not. I only know I love her.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Go away, Imogen! Where are your manners! Keep your nose out of my correspondence hereafter.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Her name?

div.stage: (Chorus begins to enter, R. and L.)

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Caroline Barry. That's the name on the doorplate of the cottage she arrived in.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: How sweet.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Do you refer to my poor poem?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Did you send me this, sir?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I did. And may her Highness present me?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: If her Highness pleases.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Little girl, this is Sir Dashemoff Daily, our Poet Laureate, And I am Locusta, the Witch of the North.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: A witch?

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Ah, don't be afraid - I'm not one of the black cat and broomstick kind.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Then tell me - am I far from Kansas?

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Kansas? Where is Kansas?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Imogen, do you hear that? She'll ask us next where Topeka is.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Listen, ye Munchkins; this pretty stranger is under my special protection.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: You are a lucky girl.

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: In proof of that I will bestow this magic ring upon her.
sp.stage: (Putting ring on Dorothy's finger, who has Xed to her.)
sp.p: Whoever wears this ring may have two wishes gratified.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Then I wish Imogen and me back to Kansas?
What's the matter? Why don't we arrive?

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: I'm sorry, but my wishes have no power beyond the land in which they are granted. They can only aid you here.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: But I want to go home. Tell me, what am I to do?

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: You must go to the wonderful Wizard of Oz. He alone has the power to transport you across the burning desert. As a member of the Witches' Union I have business elsewhere. When danger threatens, remember your ring.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Now Mistress Barry ----

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: I'm not Mistress Barry. I'm Dorothy Gale.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But, the name on the door?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Oh, that door belongs to the cottage of an old maid who lived just below our farm.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But I've made my song to Mistress Barry, and if you are not she --

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Oh, the song's not wasted. I like it very much. I wish I knew it. How odd -- I DO know it. Why, it's a miracle.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, it's the ring. Your first wish has been granted.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: We'll see.

div.head: -- "CARRIE BARRY" --
div.stage: (Dorothy and Chorus, with Dashemoff. During song the Scarecrow is carried on by two farmers and set up at stile. At end of song Chorus exits R. and L.)

lg.l: I dare not call her Caroline, I think of her as Carrie,
Her eyes like stars at twilight shine,
And they have won this heart of mine.
With glances none could parry.
And when she smiles a smile divine,
With cruelty I task her, The dainty maid knows I'm afraid
To bravely up and ask her.
Airy, fairy, Carrie Barry, will you marry me
I'm as much in love with you as a many can be.
Night and day for you alway, I pine, and pine, and pine,
Airy, fairy, Carrie Barry, say you will be mine.
Though yet untold this love of mine,
This love will never vary. I'm longing for some little sign
One spoken word, one written line.
That I may hope and tarry.
For truth it is that I opine, she looks upon me coldly.
That's why I fear when she is near
To turn and tell her boldly:

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Is that what you think of Carrie Barry?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: That's what I think of Dorothy Gale.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I'll tell you why you must.

div.stage: (Takes her hand as sound of hoofs is heard, off stage, rapidly approaching.)

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: It's a runaway.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, it's General Riskitt.

div.stage: (Bus. of Riskitt entering L.3. in manner of a flying messenger.)

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Report to his Majesty at once.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: For what service?

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: His Majesty is writing a temperance poem and he's stuck for a rhyme to Saraparilla.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: That's what I get for hiring out as a Poet Laureate. Excuse me till I find the rhyme.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Alone again. Well this is cheerful. Nothing in sight to talk to but this Scarecrow.
Well, as queer as he looks, I feel so lonely I wish he were alive.

div.stage: (COW enters and begins biting at Scarecrow's legs.)

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Help! Help!
Good morning.
Is this your cow?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Yes-es.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Well, if you don't want me to lose a leg, call him off.
sp.stage: (Dorothy motions to Cow and Cow exits R.3.)
sp.p: Thanks, awfully, for bringing me to life. Isn't this lovely weather for July?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: The ring! Another wish wasted.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Would you mind taking this golf ball out of my ear?
sp.stage: (Dorothy goes to Scarecrow and looks for golf ball.)
sp.p: My ear is on the other side.
sp.stage: (Dorothy removes golf ball and throws it down on stage.)
sp.p: That makes me one down.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: You seem well posted.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: If I wasn't well posted I couldn't stand up.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: I mean, you know what's in fashion.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: For a long time I've been just behind the stile.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Don't you think you're smart!

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I don't think at all. I haven't any brains.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: No brains?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: There is nothing there but a handful of excelsior covered with a dishrag. When the farmer was filling me with straw yesterday he said, "I guess I'll shake him". When I saw the size of his hand I knew it was on me. Then he jabbed this pole into my back and said, "You're stuck". That put me up in the air, where I've been for the last twenty-four hours.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: But you're alive now, and how are you going to earn your living without brains?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I won't be lonely. Will you help me down?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I'm getting a bad pain in my polar regions, from lack of exercise.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Can't you walk?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: No. But I'll take steps to learn.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Oh, - but you're a loose character. What's you name?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Haven't any.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: No name? But, you've a family of some sort, haven't you?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Judging from what I'm stuffed with I am related to Secretary Hay.
How about yourself? Who are you? - where did you drop from? Where are you going, and why do you go there? Tell me all about it, while I see which way the wind blows.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: My name is Dorothy, and I am one of the Kansas Gales.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: That accounts for your breezy manner.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: When I am at home I live in Kansas. Just now I am lost, and I am going to the Emerald City to ask the wonderful Wizard of Oz to help me.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: What, to get back to Kansas? Dottie, why trifle with your luck?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Behave. You are old enough to know better.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: No, I'm not! I was just born, and it will be three hundred and sixty-four days before I have a birthday.

div.stage: (Cows begins to nibble at Scarecrow's legs.)

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: How long do you think you'll live?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: If I can escape that cow of yours, until I'm used to stuff a summer boarder's mattress. Do you think the Wizard would have a set of brains knocking around his place that would fit me?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: He might.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: If I thought he could fix me up I'd go with you.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Come along. Even if he is out of your size you'll be no worse off than you are now.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: We're a nice looking couple. Suppose we're arrested for vagrancy?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: You could give straw bail. Do you know, I can hardly believe that you have no brains? How careless the farmer was to leave them out.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Wasn't he? I wouldn't treat a dog that way.

lg.l: Though I appear a handsome man,
I'm only stuffed with straw.
'Tis difficult a man to plan without a single flaw.
Though you may think my lovely head
A store of law contains
The farmer lack of skill displayed and quite forgot my brains.
When brains are lacking in a head, it's usually the rule,
That wisdom from the man has fled and he remains a fool.
So, though my charms are very great, as I am well assured
I'll never reach my full estate, 'till brains I have secured.
A-las for the man who has little in his noodle that he knows
He's under a man, and is called a rattle pate, wherever he goes.
He always does the very thing he never ought to do
He stumbles and he fumbles and is aimless.
A lobster, is he, as anyone with half an eye can see.
You can beat him sneer or jeer
for his wheels are out of gear
And it's plain he'll remain quite brainless.

div.head: SCENE III:- The road through the forest.

div.stage: DASHEMOFF enters R.I. SIR WILEY GYLE enters L.I. They enter backwards, and collide near C.

sp.speaker: Dash
sp.p: Are you one of us?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: No. Are you?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Would you like to join a revolution?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: That's my specialty. I'm Sir Wiley Gyle, at your services. Revolutions to order. Kings dethroned while you wait.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Then join our plot to put Pastoria II on the throne again.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: What! has that fried oyster returned?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: There's the Wizard's proclamation against him.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Help Pastoria? Not I. I'm next in line for that throne, my boy.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But how are you going to overthrow the wizard?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Ever since his balloon landed here the people have been in dread of his magic, and of him. He's made 'em think he has unearthly powers. But, I'll show 'em!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Going to expose him?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Expose him, or blow him up.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Blow him up - what with?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: One of the bargain-sale bombs. - If I can ever get one to work.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Anything the matter with that one?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: I'll bet it's no good. They had a bargain sale of infernal machines and bombs at one of our big stores last month; they'd bought out the stock of an anarchist factory. I got a hundred bombs for five ninety-eight, -- and not one of the darned things has worked yet.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Won't they take 'em back?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: No. They won't exchange bargains.
I'm sure this one is no good, too.

div.stage: (Suddenly throws bomb on stage L. It bounces off stage L.)

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Don't take a chance like that!

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Every time I throw one of those bombs at the wizard I get arrested for playing baseball in the streets.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: I beg your pardon. Could you direct me to a small piece of toast?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Toast?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Yes, toast. I am a sweet girl maniac, and to-day it is my fancy that I am a poached egg. If I could only find a piece of toast I'd rest myself on it.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I've heard a young man named Niccolo was the cause of this.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Jilted her?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No. He was turned into somebody else by a witch, and she can't find him.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Prithee, play upon this.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Listen, girl. Would you know your Niccolo if you met him?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Ah, you're not he, are you?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: No. But I think I can lead you to him.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Quickly, then.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: If Niccolo in his new form fails to recognize you, would you still yearn for him?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Aye! more than ever.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Listen! your lost lover is here. The witch has turned him into a wizard, - the wizard of Oz, - and he rules the Emerald City. Nobody knows it but me. The wizard don't know it. Go to him when no one is about, and grab and gag him. And when you have got him far away say to him that Sir Wiley put you on.
Don't forget -- Sir Wiley.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Ye Gods! My Nick a wizard! If he should fail to recognize me, and turn me into a sponge cake - what would be my finish? I pray thee, come and plead the cause of crime. A lady lunatic.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Her reason lost because she lost her lover. Would I go mad if I should lose my Dorothy? Perhaps, because I already love her madly. I know that, for I know what love is.

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Halt! Your precious monarch will make a final speech before the campaign opens.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Before this awful war begins I want you to understand one thing. You are the soldiers of a free and glorious country; if you win victory you will be roasted. If you are defeated you will be roasted also.

sp.speaker: Timothy
sp.p: We understand.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Then you may take my final photograph for the illustrated papers.

div.stage: (Poses. Riskitt points camera at him. Lion is heard roaring off stage L.I. Everybody shows alarm.)

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: It sounds like dinner time in a menagerie.
Come back! Come back! you cowards -- come back!
sp.stage: (Pastoria turns, sees him. Bus. frightened. Hides behind camera. Lion sees camera. Pauses.)
sp.p: Lie down, Bruno. Nice lion, good lion, sweet lion, dandelion, lie down.
Very well then, sit up, if you prefer.
Do you mean that you want your picture taken?
Something nice for the family album?
Well, you can have an appointment next Wednesday afternoon.
Or, right away, if you prefer it.
Now look pleasant, please.
How am I going to make that beast look pleasant? Shall I tell him to watch for the little birdie? No, I have it.
Look for the nice little fat boy.
No, no! Not here. Right out there.
That's it. Don't move.
Mosquitos, bothering you? Yes, there are more than usual this summer. 'Round the corner, in the next jungle there aren't any.
Now ready, again. Steady!
That will be all, thank you. How do you like your photos done, - plenty of gloss, or domestic finish?
All right. We'll do them both ways. You needn't call for the proof, I'll send them.
sp.stage: (Bus. Lion waving paw. Knocks camera over, etc, Bus. ad lib and exit Lion R.I. Pastoria collapsed, and prostrate R.I. Riskitt enters, cautiously R. behind the leg of drop. Bus. as they discover and startle each other.)

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Is your Majesty alone?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Where is my army?

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: He's in the top of the tallest tree, and he won't come down.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Have they deserted my banner so soon?

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: Yes. Here's a notice just sent from police headquarters in the Emerald City.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: "To our beloved police: Wanted, for treason, a small creature with slate pencil legs, an eye like a halibut, and a face like a cold flaxseed poultice, calling itself Pastoria II." After that description how can I escape?

sp.speaker: Riskitt
sp.p: We'll both need disguises.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: And the sooner we get them the better. See to it at once.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: I am so hungry I could eat a fifty cent table d'hote and think it was food.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Alas! that I should have chosen for a Queen one whose appetite is so stenuous.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Pasty, when you invited me to become your Queen did you think I lived on air?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I saw only your face - your lovely face.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Yes; but even the loveliest face has to be fed.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Another fond delusion shattered. Now I know that woman is but a hollow mockery. Come, let us on to my kingdom.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Come along, I'll help you get a position. Now, what field have you been in?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: All of them. I began in the pasture lot, and was moved up to the potato patch.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Do you know beans?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I should say I do. A bean vine grew up my right leg once.
sp.stage: (Dorothy sits on ground and begins to eat cakes from basket.)
sp.p: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Eating.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: What do you do that for?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Because I'm hungry. Don't you ever eat?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: No. I'm stuffed full now. Pretty soon you'll be stuffed full and you won't be able to eat either.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: I eat three or four times a day.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Is it necessary?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: How I pity you. You people of flesh must waste a lot of time trying to keep alive.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Haven't you any taste?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I admire you.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: You're a strange creature. That farmer might have taken more pains in your manufacture in more ways than one.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Yes. Think of his starting me in life with so few advantages.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: It sounds like a carette horse passing a stable at dinner time.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: It comes from behind these bushes. Dare you look and see what it is?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I fear nothing, but a lighted match, or a cigarette smoker. If ever I bump up against either of those two -- peace to my ashes.
I've got it.

div.stage: (Tin-man stands, rigid, with fife in position for playing.)

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Is that a man, or a hardware store?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: He's been married tin years and this is his tin wedding.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Did you play, sir?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Did I play? I've been practicing that lovely tune for over a year.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Why do you stand so still?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I'm rusted.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: In my joints.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Must you stay there forever?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Not if you will help me. Get the oil can from behind that stump and oil me up a bit and then I'll be oil right.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I'll rush the can.

div.stage: (Gets oil can from behind out drop and begins to oil Tin-man's joints. Bus. ad lib.)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What a blessed relief. Accept my thanks. Nick Chopper is at last himself again.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: I'm so glad we heard you. What a dangerous position you were in.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Wasn't I? If a hold-up man had come along with a can opener he might have gone through me with ease.
Here, oil my neck a little more. It doesn't turn smoothly.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Some of these tough joints ought to be pulled.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Your friend seems to be one of the light fingered gentry. I hope he's not as bad as he's painted.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: What a horrid thing for you to say, after his helping you out of your trouble.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Miss; it's a long time since I've been in polite society and I'm still a bit rusty.
Much obliged for the grease. Ah, I was not always made of tin. Once I was made of flesh and blood, as you two are.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Cut me out, please.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: How did it happen.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: A pretty Munchkin girl loved me devotedly. Often she came and held the trees while I chopped them down, and then gently lowered them to the ground. But the wicked witch had forbidden any love-making in her domains, and one day Cynthia and I were caught holding hands. She enchanted my axe so that it slipped and cut off my leg. I went to the tinsmith and had a new one made. Then, one by one, I lost my arms, head, and body, but the tinsmith replaced each missing member. I kept on chopping wood, though, and said nothing. I was happy, notwithstanding, until I discovered that I no longer loved Cynthia.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: No longer loved her? Why?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: The tinsmith had forgotten to give me a heart.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: That probably came extra.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Come along with us to Oz, perhaps you can get a heart.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Who is Oz - a butcher?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: No, no! It's city, where a wonderful wizard rules.

lg.l: "Oh, Cynthia, Cynthia, I've been thinking -
What an awful thing it was -
To be without a heart, but now
I'll get it from the Wizard of Oz."

div.head: -- "WHEN YOU LOVE, LOVE, LOVE." --
div.stage: Trio -- Tin-man, Dorothy, and Scarecrow, and exit.)

lg.l: Oh! Love's the thing, that poets sing
Their sweetest lays regarding.
And none say nay, to love's gay sway
Which wounds when not rewarding.
Naught can allure the heart so sure
As one swift dart from Cupid
And none, I know would dodge his blow,
Unless exceeding stupid.
For love's the thing, that poet's sing
Their sweetest lays regarding,
And all are gay, neath Cupid's sway
All worldly cares discarding.
When you love, love, love in mad delirium,
When you love, love, love is quite sincere you come.
there is nothing so divine there is nothing half so fine,
As the gladness of your madness when you love, love, love.
I've heard it said that Love is fed
On gifts of costly treasure,
But it's so nice, I'm sure the price,
No lover cares to measure.
All other things are quite forgot
When once your heart is captured
You guess if you're alive or not
So madly you're enraptured.
But though of love you gaily sing
'Twill turn your heart quite stony,
To end the whirl and find the girl
Is seeking "Alimony."

div.stage: SCENE:- The Poppy Field. The scene shows an extensive field of poppies, 30 or 40 young ladies dressed in costumes representing the poppy flower. They are so arranged that they practically fill the entire stage. Stage in total darkness at the beginning of this scene. Light effect is thrown upon the gauze drop. Gradually the lights are raised on the stage beginning red and gradually working up to a pale white light. All the girls stand with their heads bent forward so as to hide faces, their poppy heads alone showing. As they sing they sway their bodies and pantomine with their heads.

lg.l: Should a wandering mortal lucklessly appear in our field
Needlessly our sweet perfume inhaling
Each sense with joy regaling
Who can blame us if all our soporific powers are revealed.
While unto our sway he gives way
And must helplessly yield.
For Death, like a breath comes to all soon or late
And mortals are the sport of a mischevious fate.
So welcome the peace that we bring to mankind.
It is happiness to dream on, with care left behind.
We are poppies in fairest splendour, blooming fragrant alway.
Through the mosses and the grasses looming
Fascinations rare assuming
We delight when alone, to pass the moments are play
Every petal graciously nods
Our many charms to display.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, Dorothy! Dorothy!

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Here I am. I'm so glad to meet you again. I've lost my way.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: These poppy fields are pathless.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: The Tin-man punctured himself with a rusty nail, and I had to send for a plumber to solder up his wound.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: The Tin-man?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: A new friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I found a rhyme for "Sarsaparilla", but now I can't find the king.

div.stage: (Enter PASTORIA, TRYXIE, COW and LION at back. Pastoria is dressed as a lion tamer, Tryxie as a bareback rider. Pastoria leads the Lion, Tryxie leads the Cow.)

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: S-sh! the Wizard's police are after us and we are disguised as a one ring circus.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: This is Pastoria II, the rightful king of Oz.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: I am Signiorina Bouncerino, premiere equestrienne.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: And I am Signor Gonzabo, premier lion tamer.
Sit up, Bruno, Kiss your paw.
No, no! Kiss your paw to the ladies.
But come, we must not tarry here. On to the Emerald City.
sp.stage: (Xes R. Poppies shake their heads. All characters yawn.)

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Are you sleepy?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Very. It's the perfume of these flowers.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Yes; they make opium of them, I've read.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I feel like forty winks and a couple of naps.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Not a bad idea. I think I'll use you as a sofa pillow. You're not much as a mattress, but you'd make an awful hit with me, served rare, with mashed potatoes.

div.stage: (Lies down L. with head on Cow's side.)

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Bruno, kindly give me an imitation of a folding bed.
Will somebody bring me my shaving water and a poached egg some time next week?
sp.stage: (Lies with head on Lion. Falls asleep. Poppies shake their heads.)

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: What does this mean? My head reels. My eyes must close. The perfume stifles me. There's danger in this sleep I'm sure.

div.stage: (Dashemoff retires up stage.) (Scarecrow and Tin-man enter from platform at back.)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Where are you, Hay?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Did the plumber fix you up all right?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Oh, yes. I'm now a soldered, but wiser man.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Hello! I'm wounded too.
Got a few pins?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I want to collect my rent.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Asleep - all of them.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Let's wake them up.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: You can't. Before I turned to tin I didn't dare to cross these fields.
Their perfume brings an endless sleep.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I don't feel sleepy.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Of course not. It's the brains that go to sleep, and you haven't got any.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: But we can't leave little Dottie here.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: How can we wake her.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I don't know, but we must.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Suppose we shake her?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: No; it isn't polite to shake a lady.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What will we do?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I think she has a ring that will bring one of our leading witches to her aid.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Here it is.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: But we don't know how it works.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Who can tell us?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Oh, Locusta!

div.stage: (WITCH of the North enters L.3. coming to Dorothy.)

sp.speaker: Witch
sp.p: Who calls me!

The child to whom I promised my friendship. She and her companions in the deadly grasp of these treacherous blossoms. Heartless and poisonous flowers, dare you defy the power of the Witch of the North

Defy me, who rules the North Wind and holds the Frost King as a willing subject? for this you shall die. For this shall I cloud the sunshine, which is your breath, and chill the warmth which gives you life.

Hail, winds of the frozen North! Come to my aid! Embrace these false blossoms, and wither them with your cold caresses! King of the Fronst, you do I invoke in this, my hour of vengeance. Hurl your glittering atoms upon these cruel flowers --

Congeal their sap of life, and set upon them the icy seal of your freezing kiss, which kills as surely as does their own treacherous breath. Thus shall my enemies perish! Thus shall I restore to life these mortals who now sleep, and rescue the maiden I have sworn to protect!

div.stage:
(Poppies shrink away, droop and fall to the ground, as the snow descends and the scene change to
Scene 5: Winter Scene.
[HANDWRITTEN: The dimmer effect (elective) is worked on gauge, hung behind proscenium. Lights are lowered and when out scene changes to Poppy Field in Winter.]

Several snow boys and girls discovered at the back of platform. Snow Queen on high platform C. holding her hands out towards the audience. Snow falls from her hands. Characters are posed R. and L. with Dorothy in C. of stage. When lights have worked up to a light blue she slowly rises, turns and sees the Snow Queen and drops on her knee.
SCENE:- House and Stage all dark. THE PHANTOM MARCH. Change to Throne Scene. CHORUS discovered, THE WIZARD OF OZ enters C.

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: All hail to the wonderful Wizard of Oz.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Friends, an attempt has been made to assassinate your King. As I was about to enter the Emerald City a pistol shot was fired and struck me in the chest. After this I must have a protector.
Have we a good chest protector?

sp.speaker: Sir Wiley Gyle
sp.p: Here's a good man.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: This way, if you please.
What is your business?

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: To watch.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Antyhing else?

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: To guard.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Then you are a watch-guard?

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: You are? Good. How much?

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: How much what, sire?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: To protect.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Three dollars a week.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I can get a man with whiskers for four.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: But think, sire, I would protect you against an army. Aye, a thousand. Aye, ten thousand! If they came upon us I would run my sword through them, one by one.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Good boy! And if it came to a show-down I'd help you run.
Friends, I'll begin my performance with the magic egg and handkerchief trick.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Watch!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I have here a tame egg and a fresh laid handkerchief. Now what I propose to do is to place the egg within the handkerchief and have it disappear, and re-appear in the mouth of some innocent spectator.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Bah!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I wish it to be understood that I have no confederate. And as I have no confederate will some gentleman please step forward and kindly assist me? ----Anyone at all ----no matter who.
Thank you, I'll take this gentleman.
Watch me closely now, for you'll find that my hands are quicker than your eyes. I place the egg within the handkerchief ---so!
and with a few magic passes --- is gone. Presto! Change!

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: It's a fake -- fake -- fake. He's a faker!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Now for the marvels of marvels - my famous magic basket.
I have here a basket which contains nothing but gleamerin' blades which go round and round. To satisfy yourselves you can all step up and examine the inside of the basket.

Now, I'm pleased to know that you're all satisfied that the basket contains nothing but gleamerin' knives, and as I have no confederate will some gentleman kindly step forward and assist me? Anyone at all. You can select whoever you like.
Thank you, I'll take this gentleman.
Now he's in the basket. We immediately turn the basket over.
Then we secure the dangerous burning acid. Fire in the liquid.
The burning acid I pour all over the basket.
Don't be alarmed. I'm here. Then we secure the sword,--
The poison tipped sword, piercing the basket through and through
Opening the basket, he's gone.
Closing the basket, and back to its original place and opening up the basket, and out he jumps, as lively and hearty as ever.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: That's nothing. I can do it. I can do it.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: You can?

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Yes, me or any other fraud.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I have to laugh in my sleeve.
Laugh at him.
Again!
You see, they give you the ha-ha.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Can't you see that he's no wizard? Just a plain human humbug! If I prove that, and save the country from a tyrant will you make me king?

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Prove it.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: If he's a Wizard let him defy this bomb.
sp.stage: (Throws bomb at Oz's feet. It bounces off stage - he throws a second with the same result)

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I'm a regular bomb charmer. Merely by a glance of the eye I hypnotize the dynamite.

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: What shall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Throw him out of the palace. He's not worth taking seriously.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Some day one of these will work.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: That's more than you'll do.
Now, Bardo, the royal entertainment being over you may pass the royal hat.
Here, come back. Don't run away.
sp.stage: (Bus. Bardo passing hat. Crowd does not respond with contributions. Bardo returns)
sp.p: What's the matter, Bardo?

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: They're very sorry, but they won't have anything to spare till pay-day.

div.head: "PAY-DAY" SONG.
div.stage: (Chorus exits on the refrain. Bardo exits)
(Oz Xes R. and sits on throne chair)

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Ah, there sits my Niccolo, brooding over his love for me. Beneath that awful mask beats the heart of my own true lover.
Good morrow, most noble king!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Good morning, Carrie.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Will you come rowing me with in my garden?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Rown' in the garden? I'll have to disappoint you; I'm just going out for a walk on the lake.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: 'Tis a deep sea garden the soft shell crabs are all in bloom, and as we row we'll dredge for oyster plants. And we'll build us a beautiful house of tinted pearls and butterflies to wait on us - and June bugs---

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: She's bug house.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Come with me to the bottom of the sea and be my king-fish.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: No, I'd sooner stay here and stick to my perch.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Ah, sneer if you will; you cannot turn me from my purpose. Think, my darling think---

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I think I'll think up here.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: My head is full of thoughts; they go round and round---

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Those are not thoughts - they are roller skates.
The lady has hallucinations.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: My brain is on fire.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Yes, and I'm getting a little hot-headed myself.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Oh, Niccolo! Bewitched and transformed as you are, you must recognize your old sweetheart. Don't you remember we used to wander together.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: And now you're wandering alone. Dinny open the gate - open the gate.

sp.speaker: Bynthia
sp.p: But I have found you. Come, fly with me.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I will as soon as my wings come back from the laundry.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Niccolo - Niccolo. Don't you remember your old sweetheart? Your little Cinnie, whom you swore to love forever? Think Think! You were younger then and your hair was parted in the middle. And Nick, ---you had another face.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: That's a hard one - that's a hard one. I beg pardon, but from childhood up this face grew on me. Now, see here, my good lady, we had better come to an understanding. Your ideas are all right in a way, but even at that you're wrong. You think you're speaking to the party that you are, but you're not - you're talking to me.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Do you spurn the heart I lay at your feet? Alas, alas! I am undone.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: You're all right behind.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Monster! If I cannot have my Nick I'll have revenge!
sp.stage: (Oz takes large bullet from mouth, throws it on floor and exits R.)
sp.p: He's made of asbestos. Would that all lovers were fireproof.

div.stage: (Captain at Guard enters C. with Dorothy, Tin Woodman and Scarecrow)

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Is this where the Wizard does his principal wizzing?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Can't you see it's his palace? Haven't you got any brains?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: That's just what I came here to get.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: He'd like a few brains and I'd like a pass to Kansas.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And what do YOU want of the Wizard?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I'll take a heart.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll announce you wants. But, be warned. Don't make light of aught in his presence.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: If I made light of anything they'd cancel my fire insurance.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: We've come a long way to get the Wizard to help us. Do you think he can?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I cannot tell. He alone knows.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Don't worry, Dottie. If you have to stay here we'll take care of you.
You're in on that, Pie-plates?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: That's right, Dottie. With all my heart - when I get it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: His Majesty approaches!

div.stage: (Flourish of trumpets and enter Oz, R followed by Bardo)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Here comes the Wizard!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: What! Strangers here!

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Yes; little Dottie.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: You all look a little Dottie.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Oh no, I'm Dorothy Gale. Are you the great Magician?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Am I? Watch!
sp.stage: (Bus. Thunder each time he makes a pass with his hands.)
sp.p: All done by the passes of the hand.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then you can send me back to Kansas with a pass.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I am not a Congressman.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Brains, please.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: How will you have your brains, plain or sizzled?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Have them scrambled, by all means.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Yes, have them strangled.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: How would you like a Russell Sage thinker with just a Dash of Hetty Green.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: You're the doctor.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Bardo - my book, please.
"One pound of Angustora Phosphorus plant-tissue lyonised with tincture of fundamental and double distilled extract of Graphohoneical essence." Now, as far as I've got, how does that suit you?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: When you get it tuned up, play something.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Tuned up?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Say, Wiz, never mind that blended brain; just mix him up a little of that straight Mark Hanna brand.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Correct. How would you like to have a Mark Hanna brain?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: That's it - take it.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I'll take it.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: That's it. Take the best, it's the cheapest. The other would make you daffy. Brains, the real genuine Mark Hanna grey matter. Now, for the oraments. Would you like to have a dash of orange bitters?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Take all you can get.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Take all I can get?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: That's right. This way, please.
Oho! So you're a warbler, eh?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I'm so happy.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Well, you'll be happier by the time I'm through with you. Now do you know where you want your brains?

div.p: On the roof. Correct. Over here, please.
We start in by making a small incision. ---

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Say, Wiz, that's no watermelon.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Certainly not. No watermelon.
Ah, I see he's troubled with a little hay fever -- and an over-abundance, too, at that. I'll remove---
Now, we'll see further.
Well, what have we here? In all my experiences in trephining I never saw anything to equal the likes of this.
And the further you go the better they get - a regular squirrel's nest.
sp.stage: (Taking peanuts from Scarecrow's head and handing them to Tin-man and others)
sp.p: Search that. I don't think there's a blank among any of them. The real genuine article.
This feller is nutty.
The first thing you know you'll have rubber brains. Keep quiet if you can't keep still.
We'll start in---
at the frontal bone, passing along the seam of imagination, crossing over to the pocket containing paroties of thought---
The Gridoler----
Now----
Well, brains---
Steady - steady!
Man dear, yer losin' yer senses. Couldn't you see?
The mucilage!
A few layers of the phrenological salve, and you're all right.
There you are. Your Mark Hanna roof is well shingled.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Oh, oh, how I love the poor workingman!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: How do you feel now?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Like making speeches to the intelligent voter. I'll write one.

div.stage: (Retires up, produces pad and pencil and writes)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: One heart haben.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: What size heart do you wear?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Six-seven eights.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Wouldn't you like to be considered a big-hearted man?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I couldn't afford it Dottie. I've got lots of tin, but I hate to part with it.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Would you like to have your heart hot or cold?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Warm.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Warm?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Luke?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Here's one, left by a young lady named Sapho.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Then it's second handed. Very expensive?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Well, it used to be a dear heart, but this being bargain day I'll give it to you cheap. A dollar thirty-eight.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: There's a flaw in it. I'll give you sixty-eight.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: It's yours.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: That's a bargain.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Will you have it wrapped or sent?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I'll take it wth me.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Where will you have it?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Don't put it in there.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Sink it in those.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: What do you want, a sink, or a ---Bardo, my surgical instruments.

div.stage: (Bardo throws tools at foot of throne)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Say, what are you? A plumber?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: No. I think I'm a tinsmith.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I think you're a----wait a minute.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: What's the matter? Nervous?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Just a little excited, that's all.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I'll stop that.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Wait a minute. There's no hurry about this.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Oh, yes there is, there's others waiting.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Well, let them wait. I guess I'll call in to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Now, don't be heartless. Have a heart.
What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Oh, Wizzie, ---nice little Wizzie -- will you do me a favor?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Certainly I will - what's the matter? What are you shaking about?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Just a little case of nervous prosperity.

div.stage: (Bus. of Oz putting heart into Tin-man)

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I'll fix that.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: That didn't hurt. Shine!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I'm going to put a little absinthe on your heart.
sp.stage: (Bus. of putting absinthe on heart and putting it into Tin-man)
sp.p: There, your heart will beat in two minutes!

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: It's working already.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Don't be alarmed. I suppose you want a pair of feet.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: No, I want a pass to Kansas.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I'm afraid my Kansas passes are all cancelled.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Must I stay forever in this awful country?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: How can you call anything awful after Topeka?

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: I'm so mad, I could cry.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Don't cry, Dottie. Look at what he did for me.
Don't step on it.
Oh! Broke my brand new heart!

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: How's this for stampeding a Convention? "The time has come to cripple the money octopus. We'll pull his leg. No, we'll clip his wings, and you'll all be happy when you vote for me."

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: There go the most successful miracles I ever performed, and I'm going to give a ball to-night in honor of my triumph. The last one I attended was in Topeka.

div.head: THE DANCE OF ALL NATIONS:
div.stage: WIZARD - SCARECROW - Tin-man - DOROTHY - AND CHORUS.
(Bardo enters, followed by Pastoria, Tryxie, Cow and Lion. Bus)

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: Where is your license for this company?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: We had a dramatic license, but we lost it. We're only a moral one ring circus.

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: Is there all there is of you?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: We had a stage-struck pig when we started.

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: What happened to the stagestruck pig?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: He was cured in the last town.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: And we had a happy family, too, -- that lion and a lamb.

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: Lost the lamb.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: No. The lamb is still with us, - but beneath the surface.

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: I'll report your arrest to his wizziness.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: And if His Wizziness recognizes you, it's into the cart with Du Barry!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Ugh! Stop putting ice down my back.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Where is your army? Where is your revolution?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Be patient, my Empress of Biscuit Shooters. Feast your eyes upon that throne whereon you and I will sit together as soon as we get a chance to prove Oz a humbug.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: But is Oz a humbug?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Is he? Well, I should say he issie, Ozzie, izzie. On the earth you came from his feats of magic were chestnuts at all the church fairs fifty years ago.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Say, Hay, is this the place?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: That's where we're at.
Why so sad, comrades?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Why do our faces look pinched?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Yes. Who did it?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: The myrmidons of the usurper. Even the show business isn't safe in this pea-green town.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: What show business?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Signor Gonzabo's only original one ring circus.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Pastoria and Tryxie
sp.p: WE are it! Ta, ta.
sp.stage: (They strike pose, Lion and Cow also. Chord. Bus of Cow nibbling at Scarecrow)

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Have the animals been fed lately?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Because if that beast remains hungry I'm liable to join the menagerie against my will.
Oh, yes, she's been fed.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Why, she's perfectly amiable.
Come here, and I'll introduce you.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Thanks, we've met before.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Hold! Stand all apart.

I would speak with yonder wicked giant. It is my pleasure to think I am Jack-the-Giant-Killer. Come with me to yonder bean stalk, 'Tis but a mile high and when thou hast reached the top I will cut it down. I fain would see thee tumble.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Excuse me, I'm not good at tumbling.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Now that I look upon thee again I can believe that.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Will the Lady Lunatic kindly cut it short?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: What are thou?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Oh, back to the padded cell with you.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Have you brought home a new cook? I prithee wash the potatoes.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Now, Pasty---

div.stage: (Cynthia seizes Tryxie by arm, pulls her L. then pushes Pastoria who falls R. near throne. Tryxie exits L.1.)

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Abide thee there awhile
Thou cream-faced loon!
Where getst thou that goose look?

div.stage: (Swings axe in front of Scarecrow's face)
(Flourish of trumpets and enter Bardo R.1. Crowd enters L.)

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: His Majesty commands your presence at once.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: You're not to ask questions, but obey orders.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: If I don't know, I don't go.

sp.speaker: Bardo
sp.p: Your circus will give a special performance by royal command.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Ah, I breathe again.

div.stage: (Pastoria, Bardo, Cow and Tim-man Lion and Scarecrow exit)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Don't you belong to the circus?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: No, indeed. Oh, yes, of course I do.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Do you have to act?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Oh, no, of course not. I don't have to act, but I love art.

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: What is your speciality?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: I'm a bare-faced equestrienne, and I sing serio comics.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Whare are serio comics?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Haven't you ever heard one?

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Some people are born lucky. Here's where your luck ends.

div.stage: (Confederate enters C. Bus. Pastoria and Tryxie enter C. Pastoria throws a large green cloth over Confederate's head - bus)

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Quick, quick, my queen! The knock-out drops!
sp.stage: (Tryxie places bottle to Confederate's nose, Bus. Pastoria counting)
sp.p: 1---- 2---- 6---- 8----- 10 ----out. The rest is easy. Disguised in this fellow's clothes, I shall take his place. When the time comes Oz will put me in the trunk, then he will close the lid, turn the thing over and open it, and when he tells the people to look again they will see this trunk empty. Then I will rise at the back and denounce him as a fraud.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: And they'll make you King again.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Then I shall lead you to a palace.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: I'd rather be led to a restaurant.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Queens don't talk that way.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: But I'm not a Queen. Listen, Pasty, I dreamed last night that I was in Heaven, eating ice cream and sauer kraut.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Go back to bed. But first help me carry this man where I can secure his clothes.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Is he heavy? He must have had his dinner. I could help you lift him if I had had mine.

div.stage: (Sir Wiley enters with Guard and several girls)

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: The coast is clear. Come in - come in. Don't be afraid. I'm not. Come in, and look at his wonderful tricks. you haven't changed your minds? You'll let me prove to you that your ruler is no wizard? Then watch me. Here's his wonderful egg trick. See, a pocket in the handkerchief. And see the magic basket. Place this inside, turn it over so, --- and behold, the false bottom. Stupid, people, he has made a fool of you all for years. Rebel! Drive him from Oz. ----and make Sir Wiley your savior - king!

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Others
sp.p: Down with the Wizard! Down with the Wizard!

div.stage: (Gyle starts up stage, stops, looks around)

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Yes, I'll do it. His confederate has lived long enough.
sp.stage: (Begins to nail up bottom of basket.)
sp.p: One good turn deserved another. I will nail it up. And tries to open it he will have a picnic. A basket picnic. The Wizard will wiz for the last time to-day.

div.stage: (Pastoria and Trixie enter after Scarecrow and Tin-man exit. Pastoria disguised as the confederate, and wears long cloak)

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: H'st - would you know your king?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: No, I'm too hungry to see straight.

div.stage: (Enter entire court, Sir Wiley Gyle and Oz. Oz goes to throne)

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Welcome, my faithful subjects, to our second daily exhibition.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: This is the last he'll ever give.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: We will proceed as usual with our marvelous magic basket.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Now then Citizens, watch him. I will prove how you have been tricked for years by this imposter. Watch! Watch him! Watch him!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: You all know that the basket contains nothing but glimmering knives --if there's any doubt step forward and examine the basket.
You all know that I have no confederate. Now will some gentleman kindly step forward and assist me. Anyone at all. Anyone at all. I don't give a---- I don't care who it is.
Dinny!
sp.stage: (Bus with Pastoria. Shoving him down towards basket. Bus of Guard offering to assist. Ignore him)
sp.p: Thank you - a little bit slow. I'll have to take this man. What's the matter Dinny, have ye been indulgin'?
in the basket. Now he's in the basket... We immediately turn the basket over.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: He, he!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: We take our time in turning the basket over.
Now we secure the dangerous burnin' acid.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Go on! Go on!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Somethin' doin'.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Just a minute. I think one of the glimmering knives is broke.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Watch the faker.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Dinny, you're late.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Go on, don't stop.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Dinny, we're up against it.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Go on, we're just dying to see you do the trick again.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Yes, and Dinny will be dead if I DO do it again.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Watch him, it's WONDERFUL. Go on, pour it, pour it, pour it.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: I refuse to reign and pour at the same time.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Do you refuse?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Then drive him out of Oz!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Down with him.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Wait! Wait! He'll do it.
Go on! Go on!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Dinny, watch yourself! Watch yourself.

div.stage: (Drives sword into basket. Basket is turned up and Pastoria falls out. Commotion in crowd.)

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: This is not the Confederate. Who is this man?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I am Pastoria the Second.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Pastoria in that dress?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: It's the costume of the man who guarded that imposter's tricks. You all know me now. I am Pastoria II - returned to denounce that man and claim the throne!

div.head:
-:- FINALE -:-
STAR OF MY NATIVE LAND.

-:- "THE WIZARD OF OZ" -:-
-:- ACT III -:-
div.stage: SCENE:- Edge of the domain of Oz. Draw bridge L.U.E. Large tree R. The roots of tree have turned upward and form a cage. The scene is a study in purple.
AT RISE:- SOLDIERS led by OFFICERS enter L.1 E. and X. Sentry is left at bridge Soldiers march off up R. Officer enter guard house over R. Cooks and Waitresses enter across bridge
(Officers enter from guard house R. at end of Number)

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Who are you, and where do you come from?

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: We are cooks and waitresses and maids of all work.

sp.speaker: 2nd Cook
sp.p: And we're looking for an intelligence office.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: In your travels have you met any suspicious characters?

sp.speaker: Waitress
sp.p: Oh, everybody WE meet is suspicious.

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: Why the last people I worked for wouldn't believe that one mouse could steal a cold boiled ham.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: I'm talking of escaped prisoners - enemies of King Pastoria. They broke out of the jail at Oz.

sp.speaker: Waitress
sp.p: When did they escape?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Yesterday. There's a big reward for them.

sp.speaker: 2nd Cook
sp.p: What do they look like?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Read the royal proclamation over there.
sp.stage: (Points to Bulletin board up L.C. with proclamation on it.)
sp.p: You'll find their full description.

div.stage: (Sentry faces up stage and watches girls)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Oh, girls, it's a thousand gold pieces for the one who catches them.

div.stage: (Tin-man and Scarecrow enter down R. Music for entrance. Tin-man is disguised as a burlesque chaffeur. Scarecrow in costume of various light colored articles which might be stolen from a clothes' line. They see the group up stage and draw back to cover of guard house)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Once across that bridge and we win. Do you think we've been missed at the prison?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Missed? My boy, when we left that prison all the cells were in tiers.

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: From this description we ought to know this prisoner if we meet him.

sp.speaker: Waitress
sp.p: What does he look like?

sp.speaker: 1st cook
sp.p: "He has folding bed knees, and a face like a fightened buckwheat cake."

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: That's you.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Did you ever see a frightened buckwheat cake?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Yes; while the cream was being whipped.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Come, Harold, it's over the river with us.

div.stage: (They go up to bridge. Sentry halts them)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: Don't you know.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: We haven't been told.

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: That's it.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What's it?

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: You're it.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I've got it. This is a toll bridge and we can't go over until we've been told.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: 'Tis a merry jest, but I see no change in you.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: You see no change in me, because I'm broke.
What's the toll?

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: One fong.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: One fong? This must be Chinese money.
sp.stage: (Tin-man Xes to c. Scarecrow Xes to Sentry)
sp.p: Do you charge for anybody under five.

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: That fixes me. I'm just nine days' old.

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: Nine days?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Yes, but I'm large for my age. You may not believe it, but I was born just nine days ago.

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: That don't go. And neither do you.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Can't you trust us for two measly fongs?

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: Not unless you leave your auto for security.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I haven't got one.

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: Haven't got an auto, with that hat?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Oh, every man who wears a sailor cap don't own a yacht.

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: What are you fellers, anyway?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: MUST you know?

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: Yes; or I'm likely to arrest you.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I'm a smoke inspector in a painless dental parlor.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: And I'm a switchman in a ladies' hair emporium.

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: You don't seem to be telling the truth.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: If I could find Little Dottie and the others they might help us.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Take a look for them.
I'll wait for you here.

div.stage: (Tin-man exits E. Scarecrow motions to him after he is off. Girls turn down stage)

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: Better leave these runaway prisoners to the police and spend OUR time getting places.

sp.speaker: Waitress
sp.p: Shall we advertise first? Here are our ads, all ready for the want columns.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Here's a chance to turn the toll.
This is where my brains come in.
Excuse me, ladies, but why advertise?

sp.speaker: 2nd Cook
sp.p: We all need positions.

sp.speaker: 1st cook
sp.p: Here are the ads we are going to publish.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I know, you want everything - except work.

sp.speaker: Waitress
sp.p: You must have kept an agency.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Right!
"A young German girl would like to give Russian lessons to a Swedish deaf mute in a refined Italian family."
"A neat and willing girl would like a position as a laundress in a family where the washing is sent out."
"A refined brunette will give good advice in exchange for a happy home."
"An epileptic French dressmaker would like employment. Fits guaranteed."
"A tired blonde will teach the rest cure to a wealthy aged couple. No objection to being adopted."
"An experienced worker would like to work an inexperienced young married couple."

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: Don't know of a few families who want girls like these?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I don't know of any that WANT them, but a good many may have to have them.

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: But you can surely place a first class cook like me.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: What's your specialty?

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: My pies are something to be remembered.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Some pies can never be forgotten. I'll tell you about one.

lg.l: One day a weary traveller walked down a village street,
Did he? I think he did.
He thought he stop and ask a lady for a bite to eat.
Did he? I think he did.
He knocked upon a door and said in accents so polite,
I'm very hungry and I hope you'll let me have a bite,
Oh, you shall have my pie the young wife answered in delight.
Did she? I think she did.
Oh, the weary, hungry traveller,
The hungry luckless traveller
He took one little bite and next minute took to flight
Oh, the weary hungry luckless traveller.
A travelling man once told his wife he on the road must go.
Did he? I think he did.
And then he stayed in town and took a lady to the show.
Did he? I think he did.
He did it out of charity,
His heart was very kind
But when the usher showed his seat
He was surprised to find
His wife, with another chap,
Was seated just behind.
Was she? Oh, joy!
Oh, the weary, hungry traveller,
The hungry luckless traveller,
She murmered "You're untrue"
But he answered "So are you."
Oh, the weary hungry luckless traveller.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: There! They've gone and I'm still shy the toll.
Find anybody?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: No. Didn't find anything but a book.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: What is the book?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: "A Happy Home". In six parts.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Who broke it up?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What's a happy home got to do with a flat?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p:
The woman who owns this book can find out anything she wants to
know.

div.stage: (Officer enters with Sentry who points to both. Officer watches them suspiciously)

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I'd hate to be her husband.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: For example - Chapter 9 - how to fry eggs. Chapter 12, The married woman's pocket book.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: There's nothing in it. Go on.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Chapter 14. How to make ice water last.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: That's easy. Make everything else first. Brains.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Chapter 20. What to do when Baby swallows an alarm clock.
