sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I might try to sell it for enough to pay this toll.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: We are book agents. I have here a book that no hungry man should be without.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: No hungry man?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: It has four plates and a canvas back.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: I think you're two of the rebels names in that proclamation.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: You tell your story with a straight front.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: A straight front? Excuse me, my figure is all my own.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: I'll arrest you both on suspicion.
Take them in.

div.stage: (Soldiers step to each side of Scarecrow and Tin-man)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: This is all a mistake.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: To the cage with them.

div.stage: (Scarecrow is marched to steps of cage with Tin-man)

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Get me a handwriting expert; he can prove by my signature that I'm somebody else, and that I died last year.

div.stage: (They are put into cage or guardhouse. Sentry and soliders exit C. Officer remains.)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I say, this is wrong. We are not poll parrots.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: If I was a swearing man I'd say, "Dash it all; we're up in the air!"

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What a glorious chance to study the language of the birds and monkeys.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: It's certain we've caught two of the rebels. The others are not far off. Let no one pass that bridge.

div.stage: (Jingling of chains as drawbridge is let down. Enter Sentry and a file of soldiers, escorting The Wizard and Sir Wiley, who are dressed as convicts with ball and chain at ankles. Pastoria follows them dressed in royal purple robes, but with plasters across his face and one black eye)

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Halt! Let me enjoy their misery a moment longer.
My, but you look good.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: If I wasn't a stickler for the truth I'd say "Ditto."

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Have any of the other escaped prisoners been captured?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: We've got the What-was-it, and the What-is-it in the cage.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Good! My joy increases.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Isn't he easily pleased?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: So you're a wizard, eh? Come, - let me show you a trick. How to make the dust fly. Ha, ha, ha, give them brooms, men. Give them brooms, and let them perform the trick.

div.stage: (Soldiers bring street brooms for Wizard and Sir Wiley Gyle)

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: I'm no housemaid. I don't want your broom!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Pick that up, or I'll have you flogged. Pick it up, Sir Wiley, pick it up! Pick it up!

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Of the two evils he chooses the broom.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: My, my but you look funny. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Why so merry, dear Pasty?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Look at my new street cleaning gang. Ha, ha, ha, Aren't they a sight for sore eyes?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: I hate to see that old chap punished.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Because he gave me the best laugh of my life. It was he Pasty dear, it was he that---
Oh, my, that nailed up the bottom of the Wizard's basket just before you got in it.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Bruno take that laughing hyena away. Put him to work on the sewer.

div.stage: (Soldiers exit across bridge with Sir Wiley and the Wizard. They carry the brooms on their shoulders)

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Right face - forward - march!

div.stage: (Scarecrow and Tin-man wave their hands from cage to them as they exit and exit Officer)

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: And now, Pasty, my boy.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Please cut the word "Pasty" out of your vocabulary. Remember if you please, that I am a King. His Majesty, Pastoria Rex.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: That's all right for laying stones and opening expositions. But none of "Your Majesty" in mine, Pasty.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: And don't you want to be a queen?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Pasty, you were one of the sweetest motormen I ever knew, but as a King you won't do at all.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Your blue blood gives me the blues. For my part, I don't even know who my grandfather was, so I've nothing to be ashamed of.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Tryxie, if you desert me now my life will be as empty as a Summer resort at Christmas.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Can't help it. I'm not crochetting any worsted ties for you just now.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Won't you kiss and make up?

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Then don't kiss, just make up. You do that so well.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: Brute!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: To me, your King? Very well, we part here. I'll go back to my throne, and you can go back to your dairy kitchen, once more a biscuit shooter - and you might have been a queen.

sp.speaker: Tryxie
sp.p: That's nothing. If I had stayed at home I might have been head waitress at a lunch counter by this time.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: My, but isn't she sassy! I'll bet she's a regular Must You.

sp.speaker: 2nd Waitress
sp.p: For Goodness sake, what's a Must you?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I'm afraid to tell you, you might get the habit.

sp.speaker: 2nd Waitress
sp.p: We'll try not to.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Well here's a yarn about one.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Here we are at last. See, there's the drawbridge. This is the frontier of Pastoria's dominion. Once over that bridge and we'll be free from him, and in another day we'll be safe in the land of Galinda, the Good.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: See, a big reward is offered for our capture. Pastoria is doing his best to get us again.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: They've caught Oz and Wiley Gyle and they're working on the street-cleaning chain gang. But come on, it's dangerous to linger.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: I wish we could find our old friends the Scarecrow and the Tin-man and take them with us.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Hi there somebody. I can't sleep in this room. The mice are stealing my filling.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: The Scarecrow!

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: What are you doing in there?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: You can't do anything in here but time.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: And the Tin-man! Here's a fix.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: We can't go away and leave them in prison.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I'd like to put myself out to help you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Don't worry. We'll stand by you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How were you taken?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: After being well shaken.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'm awfully sorry. If we can't get you out we'll stay here and go back to Oz with you.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Ah, Dottie that touches my heart. If Sir Daily hadn't spoken first I'd fall dead in love with you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: If we're to attempt a rescue let's get at it.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: We can set the Scarecrow free to begin with.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: But, you ---

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Oh, never mind about me. Dottie, if you have a pair of scissors with you send 'em up on the elevator.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Scissors? Yes, here they are.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Here's a paper of pins, and a needle and thread.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What have these to do with setting the Scarecrow free?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I'm going to cut him to pieces and pass him through these bars.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Can he stand it?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Wouldn't think any more of it than a cold in my head. He can drop my pieces out of the window - you hide them in that wash basket and carry 'em off and pin 'em together again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But won't that be seriously fatal?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Not unless you lose some of me.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: He ought to be done over like a mattress once a year anyway.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: It's an awful risk, and I'm so fond of the Scarecrow. He owes his life to me. If I hadn't wished him into existence he'd still be scaring the birdies.

sp.speaker: Dash
sp.p: How about the sentries?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Are you good at sprinting?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pretty good.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Then dash across that bridge withou paying your toll, and lead them a chase. Now get to work.

div.stage:
(Dash. saunters up L. and talks to Sentry while Dor. ties scissors to a string lowered from window of cage by Tin-man and arranges wash basket beneath window. Dash. suddenly pushes by Sentry and runs off across bridge. Sentry pursues calling:
"Help, Stop thief.")
(Cooks and waitresses run on R. and watch the pursuit.)

sp.speaker: 1st Waitress
sp.p: I wonder who's escaping?

sp.speaker: Waitress
sp.p: Maybe one of those rebels.

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: He has a fine lead, they'll never catch him now.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I hope they don't.

sp.speaker: Waitress
sp.p: Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He's my sweetheart. We're wandering minstrels. He writes the songs and I sing them.

sp.speaker: 1st Cook
sp.p: Love songs, of course?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes. Here's one.

div.stage: (Tin-man whistles from window. Dor. Xes to guardhouse.)

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'm here.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: The Scarecrow is all carved, and ready to serve.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Go ahead.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Will you have some wing, or some second joint?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Both.

div.stage: (Tin-man drops a leg and an arm out of window. Dor. puts them in basket. Cynthia enters L.1.)

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: What are you doing there?

div.stage: (Tin-man continues to hand down pieces of Scarecrow)

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: S-sh--! We're rescuing the Scarecrow. It was a hard problem to solve.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: You seem to be doing it in fractions.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: 'Tis I, the Lady Lunatic. How does the Scarecrow feel about this?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Oh, he's all broke up. That'll be about all, Dottie.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Are you sure I've got all of him?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I think so. Wait - well, I'll be hanged.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I forgot his head. Here it is.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How careless of you. Had we lost that he would have had to go through life without a head.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Have you known that tin gentleman long?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Not very.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: There's something about him that reminds me of my long lost Niccolo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Help me, Cynthia.

div.stage: (They start to L. carrying basket between them. Officer enters, looks at them. Stops)

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Where are you going with that basket?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: To yonder garden, to gather geese berries for a plum pudding.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: That basket isn't yours. Put it down - Put it down.
sp.stage: (Officer Xes to it, picks up cover)
sp.p: What's all this rubbish? Officer, take it and dump it in the river.

div.stage: (Soldier steps forward, picks up basket, carries it up to bridge and throws it and contents into river) (Bus. for Tin-man during this bus.)

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: He is lost!

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: By George! What does this mean? Where are the sentries? Where is the guardian of the bridge and the cage? There is some mischief afoot. What ho! Guards!

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: He is gone, and has left the key in the door. Come down quick!

div.stage: (Tin-man comes down out of cage and rushes to bridge)

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What a calamity! What a calamity!

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Has any of him drifted away?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: There goes his leg. Quick, give me a crab net.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This will give him an awful cold.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: There's his body. Put that near the fire to dry.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p: Oh, don't do that.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: I wonder if he would mind being run through a clothes wringer.

div.stage: (Tin-man, who has thrown on Scarecrow's arms and legs enters coming down stage with Scarecrow's head)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: And here's his brains. Soaked, but otherwise intact. My! But you're pretty. Quick, let's put him together.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Where? We'll be seen here.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Hide him in the Sentry box.
What will we start with - his legs?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: No, let us put his head up first, then he can tell us if we are putting him together right.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: That's so. I can't tell his arms from his legs anyway.
sp.stage: (Bus. putting head in place in cabinet)
sp.p: There! Right in line again.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Will you take the water out of my ear?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Shake?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: I can't yet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh, I'm so glad to hear you speak again.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Hurry, you're wasting time.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Let me have an arm next, I want to scratch my nose.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What is that - right or left?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Let me see. Put that in the left corner.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Look out. Here come the soldiers.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Stay here. Don't run away.

div.stage: (Exit Tin-man and Cynthia. Exit Dorothy L. Soldiers cross from R. to L. Tin-man re-enters L. still holding leg of Dummy)

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Now then, I'll throw the rest at you - quick!
sp.stage: (Fixes remainder of dummy) (When complete, Scarecrow steps forward. Bus.)
sp.p: How do you feel now?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Like a wet scrambled egg. Is my face on straight?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Yes. Wasn't you frightened?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: A trifle. I tried to stay collected, but I couldn't. Unless you put a few more pins in my neck, I'm liable to lose my head.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Old friend, welcome back to me. I'm so happy I could sing for---- well, I'm not going to frighten you by telling you how long.

div.stage: (Enter Sentry and Sir Wiley and Oz. Oz and Sir Wiley with ball and chain,. and still in convict suits and wearing burlesque "White wing" helmets and carrying street brooms on shoulders)

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: Halt!
Get to work there you rascals.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: That's good. What next?

sp.speaker: Sentry
sp.p: You can polish up this square for a few hours.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: Here's a fine finish for a King.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: A nice job! Manicuring boulevards.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: And me massaging side-walks.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: A nice come-down for both of us.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: If anybody asks me what I'm doing I'll tell 'em I'm in business on the street.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: But just now we're working on the square.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: If I ran for King now I could sweep the country without any trouble.

sp.speaker: Gyle
sp.p: Wouldn't this be a lovely thing to give up for Lent?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: One moment. Would you oblige me with a short selection?

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: A piccolo. With that one Niccolo Chopper won my heart long long ago.

div.stage: (Tin-man blows a note or two of "Niccolo's Piccolo")

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Is that the way it works?

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Go on - go on.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: I seem to have done this before.

div.stage: (Blows a few stray notes, then plays refrain of "Niccolo's Piccolo")

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: 'Tis he! My Niccolo!

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Ah, it all comes back to me, now. My heart beats madly and tells me you are my former fiancee - the beauteous Cynthia, who kept the alligator counter in the department store.

sp.speaker: Cynthia
sp.p: Right! Take me to your copper fastened bosom.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: At last, my new heart has a chance to work.

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.stage: (Enters L.1. Sees Wizard and Gyle sweeping)
sp.p: Sporty boys, aren't they? Going out for a brush on the speedway.

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: You'd better raise a little dust yourself or you'll get into this business, too.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Why didn't you follow us?

sp.speaker: Wizard
sp.p: We couldn't. We met Pastoria and he invited us to a ball; and now we've got something on foot that we can't get rid of.

div.stage: (Bus. swinging ball on chain over arm)

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I gave them the slip in the woods on the other side of the river. Come on - the way is clear, and it's now or never.

div.stage: (Soldiers enter with Pastoria and form up near bridge L.U.)

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Aha, once more my prisoners!
This time I'll take no chances. What ho! Me headsman!
sp.stage: (Headsman with axe, and two attendants bearing block, enter up L. All in crimson)
sp.p: The men to the block! The women to the prison!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Have you no mercy?

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: I'm all out of that. May have some to-morrow; none to-day. Go on with the execution.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Can no one help us?

sp.speaker: Scarecrow
sp.p: Good bye, Dottie.

sp.speaker: Tin-man
sp.p: Good bye, little girl.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There's only one hope. They witch who saved us once may do so again. Locusta, aid us!

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Locusta! Locusta!

sp.speaker: Locusta
sp.p: Halt! The child who calls me shall be answered. For her do I invoke the aid of those mysterious powers who rule this mystic clime. Mighty Galinda, ruler of Storm and Calm, grant me, thy humble servant, one more boon -- spread infinite darkness o'er the land so that the victims of this tyrant may escape beneath its sheltering cloak; and send the spirits of the air to bear this child, my ward and charge, back to the far-off home from which they brought her.

sp.speaker: Pastoria
sp.p: What! Another cyclone? My country could never stand that. You and your companions are at liberty to depart whenever you wish.
